reviewText:
An outstanding flight simulator for those WW2 freaks. I've been playing the IL2 series since the first iteration, and with these expansions, this is by far the greatest piston flight simulator ever made. Even though it was released in 2006 and sometimes feels like it, the gameplay is still tight, flight models are still amazing, damage models realistic, and editor still the greatest ever made. Multiplayer is nonexisteant without using Hyperlobby, but that is free software. The dynamic campaigns are serious fun and can eat up hundreds of hours, and the sheer volume of them means you'll never run out

Also. Members of the dev team are STILL updating the game. Just in October, they added 3 new aircraft and a large number of features. There have been hundreds of patches which fix even tiny bugs. The community is HUGE, and replayabillity is paramount.

There's a reason why this game has the most hours of play out of my entire library.

After realizing my last review looked like complete sh!t, I've decided to re-do it and make it simple.

Pros:
-Great Aircraft Selection.
-Easy Controls, I used a mouse and keyboard, and still had a blast.
-Fantastic Damage Model, you can actually see bits and pieces, plus the pilot bailing out of his aircraft after you obliterate him.
-Engaging combat, the AI sure know how to get the blood flowing.
-Large map selection.
-Dynamic Campaign, which is very, very unique, you can play as someone in a certain rank, in a squadron, or work your way up, there's even a bit of RP elements, as you can change your picture, personally, I changed mine to a s3xy pin-up model, gotta give some lovin' to those hotties.
-Very well optimized, I never crashed once.

Cons:
-Somewhat dated graphics, however that's understandable, the game is like 11 years old, and there's mods to fix that issue.
-The AI can be really stupid at times, missing ground targets almost everytime, whether with a bomb, rocket or machine guns, or how big the target is, the AI can miss it completely if there's not enough planes attacking a target. They're better at carpet-bombing and torpedoeing.
-A few missing planes from the aircraft selection, I unfortunately didn't see any P-40Ms, or any F8F Bearcats, still a very wide selection, again, most of it can be fixed with mods.

To sum it up, with how many pros I gave this game, this game doesn't lack in anything really, it does it's job, an air combat sim. I found it hard to find any negatives, but if you've got the money, definately buy the game, it's well worth the price if you're a fan of WW2, and or aircraft.

reviewText:
Despite being a bit dated, IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 is still a top notch flight sim. The game had a number of substantial updates since its release, with the most recent being just last year (2013), though I'm not so certain if the game will see as much now with Battle of Stalingrad on the table. A plus in my book, some aircraft that have multiple crew stations can be manned by human players in multiplayer, so there's a possibility you can even get friends who don't care for flying to join in.

If you're looking for a solid World War 2 to 1946ish era flight sim, this is a safe pick and you especially can't really go wrong with it if you get it on sale. If you're new to the flight sim scene, I would suggest trying the A6M but be careful of your dive speed. If you excede 350mph, you could cause damage to the airframe --even to where the wings tear off...

Edit: I was just thinking about this review the past few days and it occurred to me that I should mention (emphasize) that this game is a flight sim and not an arcade style flyer. A flight stick is highly recommended for this game because flying with mouse and keyboard is going to give you a pretty lousy experience.

Since I'm a bit of a plane junkie, this game appealed to me greatly, so my review may be a bit biased.

If you're the type who wants something similar to Ace Combat, look elsewhere. You won't be zooming about in the air doing on a dime turns in some super OP plane, just blasting people out of the sky left and right. This game requires a great deal of patience and skill to really play well, especially online against other people. The modeling of planes and all their related systems is really good, as it should be for a WW2 flight simulator. You can fly most major aircraft from all major sides in the war, ranging from the eponymous IL-2 ground attack plane, to a Japanese Zero or a P-51.

That all being said, a joystick (preferrably HOTAS) is damn near a requirement to get the most out of this game. You can set the realism to lower levels so you won't have to worry about having to open radiator cowls, ammo counts, fuel status and the like, but IMO that takes away from the fun of the game.

If you're a flight simulator junkie like me, and am willing to drop a few bucks on a good joystick setup, this game is definitely worth the price.

reviewText: The best $10 you can possibly spend on Steam. This game is incredible. You won't find many other games that can match the challenge that IL-2 presents. The tactical depth is infinite and the difficulty is high but the satisfaction of improving your skills is immense. This is a hardcore flight simulator, so don't expect a shallow learning curve. Speed, accuracy and finesse with the controls are a must. Situational awareness is equally critical, as are reflexes, decisionmaking and tactical analysis, teamwork and communication, etc. The demands are high, but the reward is great. Of course you also have to fly your plane; proper engine management is very important, as is a basic understanding of aerodynamics and flight physics.. IL-2 Sturmovik has developed from an Eastern Front ww2 flght sim into an absolute monster! It's detailed, unforgiving at times, takes effort to get into, and has a steep learning curve. Despite, or because of all of that, it's an awesome game. Given it's pretty old now, most mid range systems will do well with this. The graphics were good for its time, and still hold up ok in the sky.

There's a huge online community of verteran players making all sorts of custom missions and skins for this game. Skins are easy to import.

These days there's plenty of action for the other fronts of WW2 as well, especially in the Pacific.

Damage is well modelled, flight characteristics have been well researched, with only a few glitches, and aircraft interiors are beautifully done. Oleg , the man who started all this, was insistent that no aircraft be imported until the cockpit was fully accurate.

I'd recommend this for someone who has an interest in flight from this era, and is willing to put in the hours to learn to fly adequately. I'd suggest starting not in your favorite aircraft, but something more forgiving like an IL-2 to learn to fly. Eventually you'll be able to handle other aircraft no problem. Landing is a big challenge, I've played over 2000 hours on this game back in its CD only days and I'm still  more nervous about landing than combat!

There's also some what if?" aircraft included

What did we get here from the old box of games? IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 it is!

IL-2 Sturmovik: 1946 is a classic WWII plane simulator with many planes to fly. If you'd ever like a classic dogfight with a friend, this game is good. It is also a good game for stuff like LAN-parties as it can host servers on LAN-only.

This game might be really old, but it is just an absolute gem. It works on new computers (tested on Windows 10 and a gaming PC bought in the beginning of 2015, works perfectly fine in Full HD resolution). The game can literally work on any calculator you own as it is like 10 years old.

Don't let that fool you though, this is quite a good plane simulator. To start up your plane, you need to do a lot of stuff before going into the skies. Physics can be as realistic as you want them to be. Unrealistic physics are the most fun, since can bounce into the sea and still fly, but realism mode changes all that except graphics-wise.


Conclusion:


+ Both realistic and unrealistic can be amazing in their own ways
+ Runs basically on any computer that uses Steam
+ Compatible with new screens
+ Hilarious glitches
+ Great choice of WWII planes and even prototypes
+ Great for LAN-parties

- Quite an old game
- Graphics are not the best in the world
- Unrealistic mode glitches are fun, but sometimes not fun for your opponents
- Render problems at some points (just check my oil lake pictures, that is meant to be a river and a lake)


I CAN recommend this game to anyone who likes their plane simulators, but not everybody will like this ancient gem. I'll leave it up to you, as I DO have more positive points than negative ones, but the negative ones are more significant.

While certainly is showing its age, it still has its strengths; such as an impressive number of available aircraft built up over the years. Where-as most games only come with a mere handful, this sim comes with literally hundreds of WW2 aircraft – and through 3rd party modification (such as CUP[www.sas1946.com]) there is hundreds and hundreds more, not just for WW2, but for WW1 through to modern. The flight models of these aircraft are also really well done – even by today’s standards. Plus it has to be said for the vast majority of these planes there is few to no alternative simulators where you will be able to fly them all in one package without huge expense or comprising flight model accuracy - at least until the newer IL-2 games have been expanded over time.\n\nMultiplayer is tricky but certainly functional and the game runs fine for me on Windows 10, but a certainly better experience with mods installed. If you have interest in WW2 aviation, or aviation in general then for the price of £6.99 for literally hundreds and hundreds of available aircraft to fly, you should have this title in your library.
